description:
I went to Pepe's for the first time about 2 weeks ago.  I have been there at least 6 or 7 times since.  It's that good.  I haven't even tried everything on the menu.  All I've had are their tacos but they are some of the best tacos I've had in a long time.  

The food is made to order and is always served hot.  They use only the freshest ingredients and the taste is superb.  I am a picky eater but once I find something I like, I stick to it.  Once I know I will have a good experience with a restaurant, I get really comfortable.  Pepe's is like that.  You can't help but be comfortable. 

They food is prepared quickly but with care.  The prices are GREAT and the portions are generous.  The first time I went, I ordered 2 tacos... I could only eat one.  So very generous portions... 

Carne Asada is my favorite although I have also tried their grilled chicken tacos.  I can't wait to try the burritos!

The owner is a really nice man.  He is friendly and he keeps me smiling every time I see him.  I have a good experience every single time I enter the cafe.  

I can't wait to try everything on the menu!
author: Kirsten W.

description:
When I received my vegetarian burrito, it was super hot. When I opened it, I realized it was super soggy which means it has been left closed in the wrap for a while. This plus the heat can only mean that the whole thing was microwaved.

The filing tasted good. But I'll pass this one next time
author: Kiran K.

description:
We love Pepe's!!!

Pepe's is simple; get in line, order the base, then choose whatever additions (some no charge, some extra) and pay. Plenty of seating in the Rincon atrium, or in our case, upstairs to our apartment.

My wife always goes for the carnitas plate, unctuous pork, with choice of beans and rice along with a myriad of fresh veg and choice of salsas / pico de gallo. They also have an "extra spicy" salsa for those who have a strong constitution. I usually get a couple of soft tacos (they have many to choose from) and share my  wife's plate, since the portions are so huge! 

The food is fresh and clean and the service is always friendly and efficient. Even a long line at the height of lunch hour goes by in five minutes and the food is inexpensive to boot. As I said, we live in the building, and Pepe's is one of our favorites!
author: John C.

description: My coworkers and I are always willing to walk a few extra blocks to enjoy a Pepe's buritto. The food is great, fast and reasonably priced. The staff are very friendly and accommodating. Great place for a quick takeaway burittos and tacos!
author: Mike P.

description: Terrible service , rude and take a look at their $9.45 quesadilla .  This was 6.50 in menu, but guy at register insisted this was the "huge" special version . What a rip off.
author: Fran M.

description: Tried the breakfast burrito this morning and it was great.  Very flavorful and authentic.
author: Art V.

description: The worst burrito I've ever had in sf. Definitely not worth your money or time especially if your on your lunch break. There are a lot of tastier places to eat surrounding this place. My burrito broke before I even got a chance to eat it and I don't know how because they only give you a spoon of each of the 4 items they put on there. Also the customer service was really horrible. I wouldn't eat at this place again even if it was the last and only place in SF.
author: M W.

description: This place is quick, cheap and good, and they give you generous portions. The carnitas is great, one of the best in the city. If you want something lighter you can get a very healthy rice and beans bowl for about $8-9. The staff is very efficient, accommodating and friendly.
author: Dan H.

description:
Lengua Burrito bites the dust!

Lengua prices have almost tripled and that has forced Pepe's, and many other Taquerias to cross off lengua off their menu! I have no idea what has caused this sudden rise in lengua cost, but it must have something to do with demand. If true it must only mean Asia! Some country in Asia, I am thinking China, has cornered the lengua market!!

Oh well, have no fear, Pepe's carnitas burrito is still pretty good.
author: Afshin A.

description:
A fav for lunch when I crave Mexican food.  Good fast food - no place to sit inside & the workers work very fast to clear out long lines.

Not authentic - but very good.

Can get a little pricey with add on condiments.  Decent for San Francisco rates.
author: Youlanda K.

description: Big fan of Pepe's and everyone in my office knows I am. My coworkers and I go all the time. Every time I walk into Pepe's, I'm always greeted in the best way by the owner. He is very friendly and always makes me laugh. I highly recommend the Al Pastor Plato Especial. It includes rice, beans, al pastor pork and several side corn tortillas to make your own tacos. The servings are pretty big and worth the amount you pay ($13-$15). Other than Al Pastor, the second best meat here is Carnitas. Their burritos and bowls are pretty popular here too. The line goes pretty fast and you can pay with a card. Not much Mexican food in the area, which makes it highly convenient for lunch.Thank you Pepe's for making me feel a little closer to home. Being a big taco fan, I would go daily if I could!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
So first of all, the breakfast burrito's are so good, one of the best in SF! I've been coming here for like 4 years and they are great day-in and day-out. Here's a secret, if you like it really spicy and if you can handle it ask for their super spicy sauce, it cures all hangovers! Also, you can call your order in, so you just pick up and go, the line can take a while as they custom make each breakfast burrito. 

Lunch is a different beast all in its self, they have the gambit of the traditional offerings and the line moves pretty quickly. On Thursdays they have El Pastor, so, yeah get that if you're there on a Thursday! 

Lastly, if you're gonna order for a large group I would recommend you order the day before or super early, they make everything fresh day-of so it can take some time for them to prep it. That's kind of the only drawback to this spot.
author: Oscar A.

description:
I'm only rating for the breakfast scene. I've never made it out there for lunch. But if you're into breakfast burritos. This is the place for you. You have to get in before 10 am though. Or maybe it's 11.

It's the best breakfast burrito in the financial district/SOMA. It has an incredible flavor. If you ask for spicy, it's ACTUALLY SPICY. They don't put two dashes of black pepper on there when you ask for spicy, like all the neighboring spots/cafes. They actually put some quality HOT salsa on it. Pepe's is excellent (5 stars) when it comes to quality and quantity... unless you're a fan of bland food or bird sized portions. 

Pepe treats you with respect and is an excellent chef! I would assume the same quality and effort is in the lunch serving as well.
author: Stephen G.

description:
During a previous (work) life, I ate here twice a week or so. Plus side: the burritos are quite large, and you won't be hungry after finishing one. The prices are ... well, it's the Financial District. Cheap food is not to be found in that area. Down side: the food is not as flavorful as Mexican should be. I've found that getting the burrito dry (i.e., no sauce) actually improves the flavor substantially. Yes, you read that right: leave out the sauce, and the flavor is better. I'm not sure how that's possible, and yet it happened.

But despite that, the food is adequate for the task.

Because most people go to lunch at exactly 12 noon in this area (no really - they do. It's freaky, as though they share a single common 'brain' or something). the lines can get really long at that time of the day. Solution: go here before 11:45, or after 1:00. They can crank out pretty much any meal within 45 seconds. Why so many people insist on piling into Rincon at the same time, is beyond me.
author: Tim B.

description:
I have to admit that the owner has a lot of charisma and very likeable, but the carne asada burrito was not. It was bland and watery. The guy with glasses who put it together was rude. He pointed at me to make the selection of what goes into the burrito. He did not even wrap it right.

Anyways this is just a preliminary review. I'd come back one more time and update this review base on the experience I got at that time.
author: Aile M.

description:
I love their customer service, everyone is ALWAYS polite and smiling!! 

My burritos are always great! Sadly, they close around 2 (like the other food court places) so I had to make a mad dash today.
author: Nae F.

description:
I came here almost 2-3 times in the past several weeks for MealPal. The menus I tried were steak burrito and chicken burrito. Overall they are decent:
Pros: Large quantity (mind you about 30% are meat), good quality of steak, flavourful
Cons: Pretty salty like any other burrito, too much rice filling as opposed to vegetable or meat.

However I'm planning to discontinue coming here for one reason - rude, offensive cashier. I usually don't rate restaurant experience based on customer experience but for this place I have to take 1-1.5 stars off purely because of that. Every time I go there, whether it's busy or not, the cashier glares at me with pissed off face asking for my MealPal number, usually by demanding "You're number!" When he wants me to repeat my number he goes "What?!" with "Don't make me repeat myself" tone. Whats's funny is his demeanour changes to rainbows and sunshine when he's interacting with non-MealPal customers. For example, after he passes over my burrito (without looking at my face) he immediately attends the next customer with bright ass smile saying things like "Sir, what did you order?" or "Thank you" with sincerity. I had no idea he had manners until then. All in all, I never felt this guilt tripped or disrespected for getting MealPal anywhere but here so I'm gonna stop coming to this place. If MealPal seems unprofitable to his business maybe he should take his menu off rather than passing on hate and discrimination towards his MealPal customers.
author: Emma N.

description:
Charged me $12.20 for a burrito listed at $8.75... No extras or anything, unless jalapeño's are 4 bucks! 

I'd bitch but what's the point? i'd still be hungry.
author: Joe M.

description:
Recommendation: From what I've seen so far, Pepe's offers the best value for your money and the tastiest burritos in the area. 

It was my first opportunity to visit Pepe's Taqueria today for lunch with some friends. I ordered a Carnitas Burrito with sour cream and cheese. It was a tremendously large burrito, and I probably could have only eaten two thirds of it if I had been trying to fill myself. Instead I ate half, and saved the rest so I could have two moderately sized meals. The staff was nice, but the glass wall is quite high so you really have to shout in order for them to hear you. Service was lightning fast and easy to follow, as you could clearly see and choose from all the ingredients added to your meal. My burrito came foil-wrapped in a little paper serving bowl with a napkin, which made it super easy to grab and go. 

The burrito was excellent! I thought there was a good mix of everything, but the lettuce was a little lacking. Also, charging $0.50 for a dollop of sour cream and another $0.50 for some cheese pushed my price up to almost $10. I think I'm going to give the burrito food truck a try to see what I can get for the same amount of money.

Regardless, this establishment makes excellent burritos and I wouldn't mind coming back!

Edit: After getting to sample some other taco/burrito offerings, I have to say this is my favorite of the bunch. With the amount and proportions of ingredients on the burrito, the speed of the service, and the price, it's definitely one of the best of the lot. Yet again, the burrito was the size of a small child, and I wasn't even able to finish half this time.
author: John B.

description:
There are a hand full of Mexican places to eat in FiDi. For someone like me, who could live on tacos daily, finding a good Mexican joint is a matter of survival. I guess beggars can't be choosers.  At least the staff could be a little more friendly. There was a special of the day happening; 3 tacos, hard or soft shell for $8.00. I love hard shell tacos, so I figured it wouldn't be a significant rule breaking event to get 1 hard shell taco with rice and beans. I place my order and the reply was a grumpy "we don't have hard shell tacos"! Me, with a smile replies, but your sign special says that you do. "We don't anymore"! I remain silent while the other Lady J in my head said, well maybe you should update your sign, so people like me are not let down. Maybe. 

As backup I ordered a small chicken quesadilla with all the fixings: salsa, cheese, pico de gallo and guacamole. The overwhelming amount  of black pepper on the chicken was bewildering. Is this how your joint flavors the food? I couldn't taste the guacamole, the tomatoes were watery and carried no flavor. What they thought was spicy about the salsa was beyond me, really it was just tomatoe juice. To accompany my petite quesadilla, I'd also ordered a side of rice & beans. Initially I was given a full side of beans. Although an easy correction, it is another check on a list of reasons why I will not be returning to Pepe's
author: Jaylena P.

description:
Awesome staff and their tacos are yum!  Do get their El Pastor!  

Opt for the fully loaded, so you can have the bomb diggity flavors spazzing in your mouth! 

They have burritos, but tacos for the win here!
author: Tiffany D.

description: This place is near my office and I was hankering for a burrito, so I thought I'd check this place out.  I got here before the noon hour, so there was no line.  Ordered the carne asada burrito, but I saw the woman behind the counter place the tortilla on top of the questionably clean lid as she laid some of the ingredients on there.  She gave the tortilla with the meat to the guy next to her who looked irritable and impatient as he asked me what I wanted to add.  There was no line, and it was just a second when he got the tortilla from the woman that he rudely asked me.  The only silver lining was the cashier who was nice.  The burrito overall wasn't anything special, was very bland, and it wasn't wrapped tightly.   It was a messy lunch for me to try to avoid having spillage on myself from the burrito.
author: Chan L.

description: 5 stars for the owner's friendliness. Long line at 12:30 but the line moved quickly and my burrito was delicious
author: Lena L.

description: I only tried the tacos here: al pastor and green chile. Neither were anything special. The salsa wasn't that flavorful, and the meats weren't particularly tender or sufficiently seasoned, in my opinion.
author: Arturo G.

description:
Here's an oxymoron: authentic Mexican burrito.  Just sayin'.

Average fuel logs (three stars) but huge (+1 star).  A worthy stop if you want dinner with your lunch.  Line goes quick so don't be too alarmed at the 40 people deep during lunch prime time.
author: Nathan R.

description:
Went here for the 1st time today and to grab a breakfast burrito.  Bad chioce.

Got there nobody was in line, the owner/manager was there but kept doing whatever he was doing w out servicing me.  After a few mins he said he'll be w you sir.  The short order cook took my order a few mins later "Chorizo breakfast burrito" I said.  

I was watching all of this and the guy did whatever including handling things w out gloves especially the finished product after going in the fridge etc.

Got the burrito and took a bite it, all I tasted was salt and burnt char.  The potatoes were burnt as well the chorizo.  Worst breakfast burrito I've tasted, and I'm sure the rest of their items including what's written on here shows how poor their food is.

Not recommended due to the poor service and food.  There are plenty of other places around including Mexican.
author: Indo N.

description:
Went here two times since I started working in the area in Dec 2016. Both times have been very reluctant but seemed the most appealing and shortest wait both times. I can see why the wait was so short and I think I have possibly found the worst taqueria on Mission street. Yes technically the address is on Spear but one of the entrances to Rincon Center is on Mission. The food is below average, they charge extra for everything including chips. But the reason for the one star is attitude and service or lack off.  
I went there last week and I guess they just closed their doors since I seen the guy just close them right before 2pm while I was walking over.  I asked if they serve one more, he just mouthed through the glass that they were closed. Guess they won't be getting my business ever. Thanks for making easier not to go the worst taqueria on Mission.
author: Chris G.

description: Pepe's is my go to Mexican place. Their carne asada tacos are to die for. Especially when it's topped with their habanero salsa. In addition to the amazing food, the staff is so friendly and treats you like family. Do yourself a favor and stop by!
author: Andrea H.

description:
Placed a catering order last week for an important business meeting today.  I get a call 1 hour before delivery time saying they can't deliver it because they have another order before it.  

I wouldn't advertise delivery times that you can't commit to.  I will not be using this location for any orders in the future.
author: Timothy M.

description:
Pepe's is a small taqueria in a mall food court in San Francisco's Financial District. It's hard to find a good burrito in that area so I was excited to try it out.

FREQUENCY: This was my first time ordering at this establishment.

FOOD: I got an El Pastor burrito that was absolutely gigantic. Definitely worth the $9 for the meal. The ingredients were spread out very well which is always important for me in a burrito. They offer different types of beans, sauces, and topping which you can customize your food with. I personally enjoy spicy food and got the hottest sauce they had which I enjoyed.

DRINK: I didn't order any drinks while at this establishment so I can't give an honest assessment in this category. From memory, I believe they had standard drinks that you might expect at a place in a mall food court.

ATMOSPHERE: A pretty standard small taqueria atmosphere for the San Francisco area. It's small and a little loud but you'll be in and out relatively quickly so the atmosphere (whether you like or dislike it) won't stick around you much.

STAFF: The staff were very quick and effective at putting together a good burrito. Since this wasn't a sit down restaurant I didn't expect any conversation besides telling them what I wanted on my burrito.

PAYMENT: Credit cards or cash were acceptable.

If this burrito was served anywhere other than San Francisco or San Diego it probably would have been a 4 star review. But there are so many amazing taqueria's around the city that serve up a true 4 or 5 star burrito that I didn't want to skew my reviews for those other establishments. That being said, this is the best burrito I've had in the Financial District. I'll definitely be frequenting this location for lunch during work unless I find a better burrito option nearby.
author: Christopher D.

description:
REVIEW WRITTEN 2017:
Keep trying, I have established the burritos just are not that good here and larger size does not make up for it. I would rather have a teeny tiny delicious burrito. I think my last trip to Pepe's happened this week...



REVIEW WRITTEN 2016
I'm hella annoyed how this place advertises serving breakfast u til 10, but they always close early. Today, at 9:18. I know I'm not the only one annoyed with this I'll see people walk in and walk out at 9:45 bc breakfast is over.
author: Nika C.

description: It's a 'meh' little taqueria. They charge EXTRA FOR CHEESE. Something feels kind of cheesy when they charge extra.  Lol. The grilled chicken is decent but the pinto beans were a bit on the firm side. Large selection of menu items for lunch though. Not sure if I will be back but it is an extra option for lunch at the Rincon Center.
author: Gary M.

description:
How much do I love Pepe's Taqueria?  Select one of the below:
A)  I go once a week
B)  I eat it every other day
C)  I was visiting SF and was surprised with a breakfast treat by a friend. Knowing I don't like burritos but was feeling adventurist, I dug into the bacon/egg/cheese/potato burrito.  I immediately thought that I was in heaven and this was God's reward to me for waking up before 12PM.  I made every effort for the rest of my trip to get it again but was able to.  I left SF heartbroken and even begged a friend to bring me a breakfast burrito on their flight to me.  No burrito arrived.  I'm currently considering when my next trip to SF will be but I got to say: a $400 trip for a burrito is quite pricey but should be very much worth it.

Answer? C

For the true review: 
I cannot speak on the joint's ambiance, pricing, variety, etc.  I can only speak on the bacon/egg/cheese/potato breakfast burrito.  Though I only ate half, it probably weighed just as much as a full burrito would of weighed at Chipotle.  Yes, it probably is because of the potatoes (which are cubed up).  They really did not flake on any of the ingredients.  Every bite was full of flavor from each contributor. 

I enjoyed my burrito with the green Tabasco sauce namely because I love all things hot.  If you're a fan of the zest and/or Tabasco, I strongly recommend you put it on the burrito for a morning kick
author: Catherine C.

description: Meh! I read the burrito reviews and went with it! Too soggy to my liking and the guy who was making it wasn't very excited doing the job! The salsa being the main taste was just a dash so I essentially had a bean and rice burrito! Meh! The owner sure made up for it having a nice chat with me ... The extras are disguised and not clearly called out so yes did pay a tad more ...
author: Megan V.

description: It's okay not wonderful, I had a taste for chicken quesadilla wanted something close to my job. Have not been amazed by anything in the financial district.
author: P W.

description:
First time visit to Pepe's. First off, I was overcharged. Second, the chicken was very dry and otherwise the burrito was not very flavorful. Given the wealth of other options in Rincon center, and the other Mexican places nearby, it's safe to say I won't be going back for a while.

Issue 1) A burrito is 7.75. I got cheese as well, which is 0.50 cents extra. The burrito was rung up at $9.52 before we were done adding ingredients and before I got the cash register. At first glance that seems within reason, but a quick mental math walking out of the center gives more than 15% above the menu price was charged. I know tax is high on food in the city, but it's not more than 15%. The owner (at the register) added some additional charge hoped I didn't notice.

Issue 2) Dry chicken, overcooked chicken speaks for itself. The rest of the overall quality was just generally poor. The other ingredients weren't very tasty, and the tortilla was also dry and crumbly. Given that we are in San Francisco, you can really do much better. At lease the size was good.

Sorry Pepe's. You would have be OK without the overcharge, but given how poor of form it is, I just can't see myself recommending the place or going back.
author: Garrett D.

description: My go-to lunch spot for great Mexican food. My favorite is the burrito bowl with chicken and extra jalapeños!
author: Doug T.

description: I love the lengua burrito. They give you so much lengua! I added guac but a scoop of guac is $1.25. Other than that, the burrito price is totally worth it. Still came under $10!
author: Joanna S.

description:
I will keep this brief...

The carne asada was mushy, flavors were mundane, portion of meat was minuscule 

Beans were bland and lacked seasoning

Overall Thoughts

The Taco Truck on Spear and Folsom (Los Compadres) is so far still the best place to grab Mexican for lunch without spending too much
author: Eddie W.

description:
The carne asada tacos are seriously the best!!!  Get it with both hot sauces and you'll be blown away by the flavors. Yummm. 

There is another Mexican restaurant closer to where I am but I like this one better. It is clean and the food is made with love. 

When I told the owner his food is great, he said he uses the freshest ingredients and nothing with fat. He makes everything fresh daily (salsa, guac, etc).
author: AnneMarie W.

description:
Huge burritos? Check.
Massive amount of meat? Check.
Dope selection of stuff to put in the burrito? Check.
Good salsa? Check.
Monster nachos? Check.
Beer? Check.

This spot checks out. Also the owner is a super nice dude.  Dope burrito joint over all.
author: Andrew L.

description: Order was up pretty quick but the chorizo y papas in my breakfast burrito were burnt pretty bad. I'm not picky n actually like a lil char but this was too much, Also hella salty. Hopefully they do better next time.
author: Aaron D.

description: Great, fast mexican food, at a great price. I had an *enormous* vegetarian burrito with tasty tofu, and I think it was less than $8. In and out in 5 minutes. I'm definitely going back.
author: Brian R.

description: I went here for the first time on Wednesday and got the Carne Asada Plato Especial. The portion was pretty large, and I could only eat about half of it. Overall, it was okay, but overly salty, and the rice was kind of bland and mushy. It's a decent place to stop by, but nothing special.
author: Cynthia M.

description: Huge fan. Most authentic Mexican food in the Financial District. I always get the carne asada burrito and fill it with all the toppings and it's huge and keeps me full all day long. Very nice staff, always remember my name and are cheery and friendly. I hit up this place at least once a week now. Get there early cause the line will get long and the Rincon center gets really loud.
author: Dusty N.

description: I adore this place. Taco Tuesday's are a good deal! I just had that for lunch. The owner is so charming!!! The tacos make me feel better when I'm under the weather. It's basic style, which is best in my opinion. (Handsome guys tend to go here by the way.)
author: E. R.

description: You have to ask for light potatoes but otherwise it's one of my favorite breakfast burritos in the financial district of San Francisco
author: Garrett W.

description:
Ordered the carnitas burrito today.  It's huge.   I think it's still a little pricey and they charged 50 cents for a little sprinkling of cheese.  Which I thought was tacky.

Service was pretty aloof and gruff.

We did like the flavor but I think there are better burritos elsewhere, but  this place seems good enough if you are in area and have a hankering for Mexican food.
author: Foodlover B.

description: This food will go right through you, and I have a proud digestive system that can handle heaps of Taco Bell. More importantly, the food isn't good. Perhaps most disappointing was getting overcharged, informing the manager in the fancy pants that I was overcharged, and then having him threaten to throw my food away. Not a great spot.
author: Garrett L.

description: I've been to this place twice & both times ordered the breakfast burrito. It's definitely the top three breakfast burritos I've ever had. They fill it with scrambled eggs, potatoes, cheese, hot salsa, and your choice of meat.  I always get the chorizo because each burrito is made to order so they burn it a little giving it that smoky flavor. Because the portions are so huge, I usually eat half of it for breakfast & save the other half for lunch.  Breakfast & lunch for under $5...Now that's a SUPER DEAL!!
author: Wina K.

description:
The tacos were a sloppy mess and the service was rude. 

We figured we would try some tacos, at $4.50 with tax they were a little expensive, even for FiDi. 

The folks behind the counter we snappy and did not help with any of our questions. Behind the counter was sloppy with spills and not organized. 

They were not busy, but the ingredients were just slopped on to the tortillas, which were barely toasted, so ended up so wet and soggy at to be inedible. 

Definitely not a recommend. Good thing there are 12 more taco joints in walking distance.
author: Wayne B.

description:
Hands down, Pepe's massive chorizo breakfast burrito is the hidden gem of downtown of San Francisco.

It's good good, I've gotten half a dozen people from my office to walk over and get one.

They always come back for another sooner or later. One of my coworkers I believe ate half for breakfast and half for lunch because it was so massive.

This is a "can't miss" breakfast item and the guys here are so nice!
author: Doug R.

description: bomb, fresh Mexican food. Chipotle-style but more authentic. Chile verde or pollo asado burrito... seriously can't go wrong
author: Nico C.

description:
Amazing food (except the asada, but I don't like steak anyway). The chicken is to die for, grilled just like I like it. The two sauces are so delicious I get them both.

If you don't like something you get off the menu, I encourage you to try something else. The beans and rice are a bit plain, but honestly, aren't all beans and rice?
author: Janie L.

description:
I hit this taqueria up at minimum once a week.  Pepe's is my go to place when I'm craving their carne asada plato or carne de cerdo chile verde (which is DELICIOUS), also the breakfast burrito is AWESOME.  There are many other platos and menu items I haven't tried, but I'm sure they are just a delicious.

As for the customer service - what can I say I've been coming to Pepe's for years and I guess, unlike a few others here on yelp complaining, I am greeted with smiles from all, the service is quick and precise.  The owner is a very nice man who engages in conversation with his regulars and always has complementary things to say.

As for the most recent review about them 'slopping' things on the taco - I ask you sir, how many Taquerias do you frequent?  This is a common practice and pretty standard of all Taquerias.  As with the counter being messy, I've never seen it messy, even on a busy day.

Would I recommend Pepe's - ABSOLUTELY!
author: Cris B.

description: I ordered a breakfast burrito not only were the potatoes burnt but the burrito itself was salty as hell! Breakfast burritos at McDonald's are way better...
author: ernie e.

description:
$5 minimum to use your card.

Nothing special, a little overpriced. I had carne asada tacos (under seasoned) & my friend had a burrito. He says it was "whatever".

Not to mention the chef was playing with the ingredients with his bare hands.. which I'm assuming were clean, but the sight of it disgusted me.
author: Catheria S.

description:
Nothing special. The food is pretty subpar. I ordered the carne asada burrito. Steak tasted old. Beans tasted like it was from a can. Rice pretty much filled up the rest.

If you're desperate for Mexican, don't go here. Go accross the street to One Market or order from 201 Taqueria a few blocks down. Your money is not worth it here.
author: Jonas M.

description: I pride myself in my understanding of SF, and particularly FiDi, breakfast burrito offerings. Pepe's is phenomenal and I'm disappointed in myself for taking so long to try it. I've only had the Chorizo burrito so far, but it was great. Good size, melted very nicely and lots of flavor in every bite. They also offer breakfast quesadillas which I will try next time. Definitely recommend this place.... new favorite down here.
author: Garrett W.

description: The breakfast burrito's are sinfully delicious. You get a choice of bacon or chorizo and it's big enough to split with someone else and still be satisfied. Their burrito bowl has quickly become a favorite at my workplace with the low carb crew since it's basically the insides without the tortilla. I like going for the fish burrito with the green tortilla or the chicken burrito. Best burrito in a 3 block radius.
author: Norris T.

description: Always a great place for an authentic mission style burrito. Been coming here for years with no complaints. Great service and great food!
author: Andrew F.

description: I had the super burrito here and the tacos. Both were very ROTM and pricing wasn't too bad. This place won't blow your mind but you won't walk away with a bad impression either. The neighborhood can be a bit sketch but okay during the day.
author: Richard L.

description:
Ordered their Platos Especials with rice, beans, lettuce, tomato, cilantro, onion, salsa & warm corn tortillas - Carne Asada (Grilled Steak) for $7.25

I like it, I wish they can make their sauce much spicier though then I will love it, definitely! :)
author: Jackie A.

description:
FiDi Food is either:
A) Expensive and AMAZING
B) Moderately Expensive and ok
C) Cheapish and terrible.
D)Expensive or Moderately Expensive and Terrible.
This is just the situation. 

This place falls under category B.

I like how fast it is.  I tend to find the meats on the salty side.  But after tax I can get a huge grilled tortilla burrito for under $7.  Also 1 taco is really 2 tacos because it has two tortillas and is super overloaded with yummies.  Generous portions!  The don't charge you extra for any of the possible burrito fillings.

 I highly recommend the pork verde!  It's very tender and not too salty. Also the fresh lettuce, tomatoes, onion, cilantro and the corn salsa make your cheap meal feel much more upscale.

The staff is always very friendly and never push a sale.  I was debating between 2 and 3 tacos my first time and the owner was like "2 is going to be way more than enough."
author: Susan C.

description:
COME HERE FOR BREAKFAST!! The chorizo breakfast burrito is amazingggg. Chorizo, two eggs, potatoes, and salsa on a large flour tortilla all for under $5. It's so easy to make this work for breakfast and lunch. And it comes with a kitchen crew that's eager to talk and brighten your day.

CASH ONLY UNDER $5.

To the chefs: the burrito was a tad more oily than I would have liked it to be, and I think it'd still be as good without the oil you added to the potatoes.
author: Jason T.

description: Went in for a breakfast burrito against my better judgment.  The thing tasted like the grill! So, I paid $8 to learn what their grill tastes like. Pepe, is his own worse enemy, in a city full of restaurants.  He's from the new school of restaurant owners that have no clue that they are actually supposed to be nice to their customers. And, no, telling someone you just overcharged that they can go somewhere else if they don't like it, is not what running a business in the hospitality industry is about.  Pepe, hospitality means: "the friendly and generous reception and entertainment of guests, visitors, or strangers."  Feel free, to open a business that doesn't rely on interacting with the public, if you don't like that!
author: Ebony S.

description: mmmm drool carnitas burrito how you like it...
author: Greg F.

description:
Second time coming here for the breakfast burrito.

If you get there with no line, between 7 and 10am, the burrito is pretty good.

I walked in at 10:04 with no one in the place and the cook would not make a breakfast burrito. So I went to Cicil's outside. And it's a better burrito anyway!
author: Ben B.

description:
Can't stand Burrito 360 - it's just not Mexican food! - and I don't always have cash for the taco truck down the street, so decided to give Pepe's a whirl.

Not bad, you just have to remember to ask them to put sour cream and cheese on your order, since they don't offer a "super" version. Spicy sauce wasn't really that spicy at all either. It's hard to find good Mexican food in the area, but safe to say this will do when you get a craving.
author: Alita M.

description:
Two words: FISH BURRITOS!!!
 
And the fish is not some greasy fried fish, oh no. It's cubed cod simmered in a tomato based sauce with onions, garlic and bell pepper. DELICIOSO!!!
author: John G.

description: Great food, and the owner (usually at the register) is a really funny guy (when he's in a good mood).
author: Alexander R.

description: Not bad, but nothing special.  Pretty much if you are desperate for Mexican, this place will serve well.  The 3 taco deal on tuesday was not nearly enough food and the taste was ok, but didn't wow me, though the condiments were good quality.  $6.50 and I needed a yogurt after to fill me up, but I might return again to try another selection.  The normal 3 taco price would he a total rip off ($10) and would earn a 2 star rating were I to purchase that, but I never would, so really this rating is for Tuesday only.  With all the 4 and 5 star choices near my work, not really a reason to go here, though.
author: Marc S.

description:
To-mat-oes.

Say it with me.  Tomatoes.  For some reason, many establishments that claim to hail from south of the border do not understand the difference between pico de gallo, salsa, and just plain old tomatoes.  Maybe it's because a large portion of the population absolutely abhors them and will only eat them if they are accompanied by cilantro and blended, but I love them.  Salmonella scare be damned, I'll eat those suckers on everything.  

Pepe and his (or her) crew do it up right for me.  I'd like to convince myself that I'm eating healthy after going to the gym, so I get a tostada plato.  So I put cheese on it, which isn't very healthy, but I don't actually eat the "tostada"- I just consider it to be a salad on an edible plate, covered in a big, red, juicy pile of tomatoes.

Quick and easy.  Just the way I like it.
author: Pam S.

description:
Another mediocre establishment in the Rincon Center food court.  

Turn around and walk two block to Los Compadres Taco Truck.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/P1XZeSdImfB6Pqqt4JHhcQ

I'm so sad for forcing myself to buy lunch from a place like this just to move a step closer to reaching my personal goal of trying all restaurants in Rincon Center.  Today, I SO much preferred noodles at Sorabol.  Now, Wrap to Go remains as the only place I've never tried in that building.
author: トモ T.

description:
For an inexpensive, fast Mexican lunch, this is the place.

When I go by myself, I get a taco (al pastor, chicken, whatever).  Get them to pile on the lettece, tomatoes and cilantro and I have a delicious meal for under $3.50.

When I go with a coworker, we share either the burrito or the grande quesadilla with meat (chicken is a pretty good choice).  Again, less than $4.00 a person.

It's fast, it's cheap, and it's pretty decent.  For someone who can't stand (or afford) eating $10 lunches everyday, it's just about perfect.
author: Cindy C.

description: Great lunch place and reasonably priced on the entire menu.  Chicken dishes are the best!
author: R J.

description:
- Rice and Beans Plato or Burrito
- Toppings to taste
- So Simple and full of flavor
author: Evan F.

description: Great food and staff.   I have been going here at least 1-2 times a week for several years and have always been more than happy.  Does not get better than this!
author: Hank G.

description: Went Yesterday, And Got A Rajas Veggie Burrito. These Are Soo Good! I Usually Dont  Like Green Bell Pepper But These Are Soo Darn Good! Great service Everything Is Really Fresh! Only Thing Is Burritos Are Really Big And Can Be Messy.
author: Susana R.

description:
I like this place because it's fairly good quality and I don't find the prices to be very high given that it's in the financial district.

My favorite part is that, unlike a lot of burrito joints, they don't charge you the full price of a meaty burrito when all you want is beans, cheese and salsa. You can actually get out of there paying about $4 for a burrito. Amazing.

My one complaint: they close at 2 pm on Fridays! Some of us don't take our lunch until 2. Poo!
author: Nicholas F.

description:
$7.68 for a chicken burrito (black beans, tomato, lettuce, hot salsa, onions) with a teaspoon of guac added.
Good?  Sure, not bad, but not amazing.
They're fast here.  And they're friendly.
This is a take out only place, open for lunch in the Rincon Center food court.
author: Kev M.

description: My coworker and I would always go here as a plan B for Mexican food for lunch if we didn't feel like spending a lot at Orale Orale.  Their burritos were big and filling, but still very pricey but that's understandable considering that they're in the Financial District.  Being that there aren't too many choices for a Burrito in that area, I'd say their stuff it pretty decent.  Give it a shot for lunch if you're in the mood for some decent Mexican food.
author: Rodney H.

description: Love their Taco Tuesdays! Three tacos for $5. Their burritos are pretty delicious too. My only gripe is that they charge extra for stuff that should be standard with a SUPER burrito, like sour cream and guacamole. Aside from that, the burritos are really good and the meat doesn't have that burnt gristle that some other burrito places leave behind. Two thumbs up!
author: Mariela D.

description:
The burritos are good. I'm a big fan of the lengua which is very tasty. I was sad that they raised the price though so now it is the most expensive of the burritos!

They are fast; looks clean; friendly service.
author: Rodrigo F.

description:
I am quite a fan of Pepe's veggie tofu burrito. Yum. They're pretty generous when it comes to packing the burrito with yummy goodness. I usually cut the burrito in half for 2 small meals.

I like this place because 1) the food is of a good quality, 2) prices are decent even though it's the Financial District, and 3) they're super fast! Obviously, you're not getting authentic Mexican food here, but it's a great place to satisfy that weekday burrito craving!
author: Waz W.

description:
Wow. I know it's the financial district and all, but comeon.......$2.75 for guac, sour cream and cheese?  And another $2.00 for a side of chips?  A side of chips?  

The food here isn't great either.  I see no justification for the gross price gouging that goes on at that place.  

Good luck staying open.
author: a y.

description:
I have seriously changed the ratting from a 2 star to a 3 star and back again 4 times now.  I really wish yelp would let us give half star ratings.

The place isn't bad but it definitely isn't good. I think I want to give them a 3 star rating because the manager/owner was really nice. But $13 for a taco, super burrito, and coke put me over the edge. I know its in the Rincon Center but come on now

Carnitas Taco - Not bad at all. Much better than the burrito. Meat was tender and had a decent taste. Also the tortillas tasted really fresh

Al Pastor Super Burrito - Really basic burrito. I always cringe when a place puts lettuce in their burritos. Luckily I looked at the ingredients list before hand and caught it. Seriously, who likes lettuce in their burrito. The rice was decent but the meat was a little tough.

If I am ever back at the Rincon Center I will just go to Sorabol
author: Jeff P.

description:
All I have to say is that Jose will be disappointed with Pepe. 

I had a burrito at this establishment, and it was OK. Just need to improve the ingredients a little.

The meat had no flavor and the beans were bland.
author: Marcelo B.

description:
Don't waste your time. 

I've eaten here about 4-5 times in the past year with hopes that one day it will be decent. I work right next door so I've eaten here out of burrito desperation rather than choice. 

They charge extra for everything! Guac is an extra $1.25 & they charge for items that are free at every taqueria like chips, salsa, jalepenos, etc. I was sucked in for thier deceiving 3 tacos for $5 deal. They give you 1 tortilla per taco which means it breaks after one bite. Instead of giving the normal amount of meat in each taco they grab one scoop & divide it 3 ways meaning you barely get any meat. At least the produce was fresh.

If you want a rude owner/cashier who gives u lettuce tacos & charges for anything w a hint of flavor then this is your place. If you like good food & not being ripped off, then eat elsewhere. 
Anywhere else.
author: Alex R.

description: Fantastic food, value and location. Pepe's food is flavorful at a price that can't be beat. The carnitas and grilled chicken are amazing with the veggies always fresh. I love eating here, sadly I am not always working in the city.
author: Annie C.

description:
Yes, the guys are nice and I will definitely give them another try for breakfast and maybe even lunch at some point, but they forgot the eggs in my breakfast burrito. 

Also, beware the $5 minimum for credit cards if you don't typically carry around cash.  In a bit of savvy pricing, the breakfast burrito is $4.75 and since the minimum card purchase is $5 I purchased a bottle of Coke...$7.66 was my total.  Did I really just get scammed into paying nearly $3 for a bottle of soda?  Yes, I did.
author: Jason R.

description: Didn't have high expectations, but the chile colorado burrito was actually pretty tasty.  The wrap was a little bit too flimsy for my taste, but all the produce tasted fresh and the meat had tons of flavor.  To top it all off, i was $6.30 for a hearty burrito!
author: Jeff N.

description: Due to the limited selection of Mexican Food in the Ricon Food Court, this tends to be the go to place if I want Mexican.  Today was the 3 soff/hard tacos for $8.00.  No denying, for the SOMA area this is a good price.  I ordered the Tacos Shells.  To my pleasant surprise, on my first bite I was surprised to have very chewy shells straight out of the box.  The shells are not warmed up one bit.  The shells are exactly the ones I use at home and are instructed to toast the shells a bit so they are crunchy. I asked  "Pepe" the Owner, if they did not toast them.  His response was they already come toasted.  I mentioned at home we toast them for a crunchy and he blew me off by saying "I'm not sure what you do at home".  Since I'm at it, i've also had issues with their pricing for add-ons.  They have Nachos Con Todo.  I'm fluent in spanish and I know what "todo" means.  According to Pepe, "Con Todo" is defined to his liking.  So be careful when ordering the Nachos Con Todo.  The price on the Menu is not what you will get.  The owner tends to have a customer is never right policy.  So ask questions or else you'll have a surprise when you are charged and open your to go container.
author: armando t.

description:
Strange things happen in food courts.  Pepe's Taqueria, according to its neon sign in the Rincon Annex, has a little printed menu for Taqueria Aguilella.  Both the overhead menu and the printed menu agree that the #1 item is a Burrito Grande de Carne Asada (grilled steak), with rice, beans, lettuce, tomato, onions, and hot sauce.  

"I'd like a burrito de carne asada," I say to the line cook.  
He heats a tortilla and puts some rice on it, and then asks, "What kind?" .  
"A burrito grande de carne asada."  
He gives me a puzzled look, standing still.  The cashier asks, "What kind of meat?"  

OK.  The menu shows carne asada, carnitas, pollo, and al pastor.  There's no hamburger.  

"Steak,"  I respond.  
The line cook adds hot grilled steak, and hands off the burrito to a second line cook in front of the vegetables.  
"Lettuce?" 
"Yes." 
"Tomato onion?" 
"Yes." 
"Mild or spicy?" 
"Spicy."  

So, I've taken the #1 item on the menu, presumably the most popular, translated it to English, and then specified it one ingredient at a time.  This, with a Diet Pepsi, is an $8 lunch.  The steak is almost too hot to handle, and the vegetables are ice cold, creating a very interesting cubic foot of hand-held thermodynamics experiment.  

Weird.

The burrito was authentically explosive, though.
author: David D.

description:
I only order one thing from this place, their jumbo quesadilla with meat.  Jumbo is a very good word to describe this beast.  It is a big boy, filled with cheese, the meat of your liking, and other toppings that you choose.  I only finish it on rare occasions and I always regret it when I do because I spend the rest of my day with my belly stretched to it's limit.  You do have to pay extra for sour cream and guac but that is standard at most places.

p.s.  Pepe seems to be a middle aged Korean lady.
author: Luis M.

description:
I can't believe I am giving this place four stars. Not a bad burrito, and plenty of menu options. Really liked how they offered a veggie options for only $3.25 - plenty of black beans, rice, lettuce and tomato, a completely filling burrito. Can't remember too many burrito joints with sliced tomatos and lettuce standard.

Would have gone five stars if there were tortilla options, but close.
author: Jason B.

description:
Not a bad showing, Mr. Pepe.

The fast food style setup doesn't look good, but there's a couple good things going on with the burritos here, mainly the grilled (not steamed) tortillas and a wide variety of veggies to throw on.  I went with the carne asada and found the meat to be nicely done just right - neither under or over cooked.  My only complaint really was they go pretty high on the rather generic spanish rice.

Also, the hot salsa had a healthy but not overwhelming kick.  Nice.

Doesn't catch up with Los Compadres, but definitely beats Bur-eat-os
author: John H.

description:
I got a carnitas burrito for lunch with a friend and was satisfied.  It had big chunks of tender carnitas, though they could have had a bit more seasoning.  The salsa was nice and spicy and the burrito itself was really big.  At the same time, I didn't feel disgusting after eating the whole thing like I do after eating a Chipotle burrito.

Not the best burrito ever, but it's fairly cheap and for not being in the Mission district, I can't really complain.  I was thinking about getting tacos but the value of the burrito seemed much better.  $3+ for each taco seems a bit ridiculous for me...
author: Naoko M.

description:
Located in the Rincon,well thought it would be ok and didn't really have any high expectations like a margarita waterfall flowing or anything.Just decent food.

So,got the chicken tacos with a drink.The place overall when ordering was not busy,prices so-so and service was friendly
(2 stars for that).Everything seemed fresh,but I thought it tasted ok.Nothing special and nothing great.
author: Dani D.

description:
I love the way you get to customize your food at final stage of assembly (kind of like subway).  

The beef and chicken are top grade, the other ingredients are aways super fresh.  And the owner greets everyone like a long-awaited friend.

Plus its reasonably priced in the middle of Fidi.    I'm there like 2 times a week.
author: erin b.

description:
Are you kidding me?
I wouldn't eat the nasty waterlogged slop here again if it was free.  And its not free--its overpriced.  And the people who work here are unpleasant.
I really wouldn't be surprised if I found out you were totally kidding me with this place.
author: Skeptical Spee ..

description: Been coming here for years and can't get enough of their Carne Asada burrito! Trying their "regular nachos" for the first time and it's nothing to write home about.  But hey..It's fairly reasonable in price (for the Financial District, that is) and they serve fairly generous portions. Service is quick and friendly.
author: Nate P.

description: It's a good thing this place is in the Financial District where the rich guys in suits don't know good Mexican food, cause this place sucks. I ordered a chicken burrito on my much too short lunch break and was not impressed. TEN DOLLARS (!) later I was looking forward to my new burrito when I was sadly disappointed. The chicken was dry, the rice overcooked, and the lettuce limp. I couldn't even finish half of it and I was hungry! But then again, what can you expect from a business building kind of place?
author: Stephanie W.

description:
You're not on 16th and Mission and this is no Mission taco joint so adjust your expectations accordingly.  This place is Rincon mediocrity at its best but they are fast, cheap and efficient.  Being a taco connoisseur, I've developed a standard in which I judge all tacos.  The meat and tortillas are fresh but the tacos are overstuffed with lettuce and tomatos.  It's like a little burrito!  The salsa has no kick and they serve sour cream as a standard.

The burritos are good but, again, overstuffed with too much filling and not enough meat.  The meat itself is ok - it tastes like boiled beef, but I'm not sure if it really is boiled.  No chorizo, lengua or cabeza but it is Rincon, I guess.  I actually go here quite often when I don't have time to walk over to the roach coach on Folsom but still need a taco.  Right in the middle of everything - not great, not horrible - three stars.
author: Tony M.

description:
You would think that in a place - as popular as the Rincon, where most of the downtown/financial district goes for lunch - they would have a GOOD mexican place. Right?  Oh, so wrong. I've given them 2 chances now... and it's really not great. 

First experience:  Got a burrito - because I didn't see nachos on the menu. (i was blinded by hunger). It was, ok. Nothing special. Just a burrito. Nothing like the burritos out in the Mission. Now those, are a deal!

Today's experience... I had a craving for nachos... and so I got them. 1. the cheese - gross. 2. the meat, tough. 3. the salsa, soupy. 4. the toppings, not so impressive. 5. just not great. 

And then - my stomach hurt! Not fun. NEXT!
author: Lisa L.

description:
One star; one word...gross.

I've been there twice in an attempt to find good or at least decent mexican food for lunch in SOMA during the week.  The first time I had a carnitas burrito.  The person seemed confused when I asked for carnitas...como? This is a mexican food place right?  The carnitas was dry and hard, more like jerky...yuck!!

I recently went back because I had a severe craving for nachos. Trust me if the nacho craving wasn't so severe I wouldn't have gone back. This is how the nachos started...a to go box with tortilla chips with melty nacho cheese on them, then carnitas (yes I'm a glutton for punishment and tried them again) some beans then some guacamole.  I was being rushed out of their so fast I couldn't decide what to put on the nachos...it wasn't even busy, there was only one person in line behind me and I was there before the noon time lunch rush so I'm not sure what the deal was.  The guy also seemed irritated that I wanted meat on my nachos, is this such a weird request?

The service was not good...not very friendly.  Back to the nachos; the carnitas was not dried out this time but it was super fatty (gross!) and had no flavor. Also lacking flavor was the guacamole...if that's even what it was. The chips were too salty and when I get nachos from a "mexican food place" I expect real cheese not nacho cheese.  Please don't get me wrong I am not a hater of nacho cheese; I am a lover of nacho cheese, specifically que bueno BUT that kind of cheese is reserved for nachos at baseball games and other sporting events or at parties with a nacho bar.  Nachos from a mexican food place should have real cheese that is piled on top of the nachos and then melted in the oven. Oh and yes I am a nacho connoisseur in case you were wondering.
author: Kel E.

description: Solid three stars for the $4 breakfast burritos. Made fresh with love, super filling and cheesy, and they have chorizo! The end.
author: Claire C.

description:
I generally go to lunch about one time per week because the Financial District is not cheap for mid-day eats.  My friend's and I usually hit the Rincon Center, and I head straight to Pepe's as a rule.  

The prices are totally reasonable.  The service is fast even when the line is out the door.  The food quality is good and is consistent.  The portions are more than sufficient.  The staff is friendly.  What else are you looking for in a lunch place?
author: Ken B.

description:
This place is great. It's located inside Rincon center food court. 
I go to Pepe's for lunch all the time, at least 2 times a week, I especially like their Fish Burrito - Excellent cod!  Reasonable prices as well, I mean, for Financial District anyway.
author: Leo Z.

description: How can you ruin a bean and rice burrito? Here's how: serve it with 3 tablespoons of rice, two tablespoons of beans, add a heaping side of attitude, and charge $5.50 for it.
author: Sue S.

description: I just paid $10 for the blandest burrito I have ever eaten, I think I threw half of it away because it was so bland. It should not be even classified as food. I had frozen burritos you buy at Trader Joe's taste better than the shit Pepe's was serving up as quote en quote food. Don't go here
author: Lawrence F.

description:
As a native of California I have had my share of burritos and Mexican food. I met a friend of mine who works in the Rincon Center for lunch. I noticed Pepe's and decided to give it a shot. I ordered a pollo asado burrito and a steak taco.  

I must say that I was extremely impressed with the food. The salsa verde was a perfect compliment for my burrito, but the only problem I have is that I didn't get to eat my steak taco. This was due to the fact that my burrito was huge (definitely something that I don't mind). 

I'm not in the city too often, but when I am I definitely will try and stop by Pepe's again. Definitely recommend it.
author: sebastian p.

description: I liked the vegetarian burrito with rajasm, sauteed peppers and onions in a sour cream sauce. Both black and refried beans are vegetarian. Tasty and I felt good a few hours after eating it, which is a sure sign the ingredients are high quality. Next up - the breakfast burrito!
author: Robert T.

description: I like Pepe's.  I usually get a carnitas taco with lettuce, cilantro, and guacamole.  They are not stingy with the meat and toppings, so one taco is plenty.  Rice and refried beans on the side.  All of this costs me about $6.50.  I have also had burritos here, and they are good as well.  They have this "rojas (?)" sauce that is creamy.  I've never seen that before, and it is pretty tasty in a burrito.  I can't see anything bad about this place.  It's as good as any taqueria in the mission.
author: Kandi K.

description: Owner makes bad reviews about other places and great reviews about his place.  I tried food here and it is not good.  The taco truck outside is awesome and much cheaper!  Def. will not come back
author: Willy G.

description: I stop by once or twice a week for my favorite #4 pork burrito. Pepe's always has the best slow seasoned cooked fresh pork as well as fresh lettuce, tomatoes and other toppings. The place is clean and friendly. I bring friends and colleagues often.  With all the different options of eating in the city, I still find my self coming back to Pepe's for the quality of food and hospitality of the staff. Top on my list for a good full lunch meal.
author: Kevin b.

description: This place is so disgusting. Everyone I know who ate here got food poisoning (recently - since the NEW ownership has come on). It's a total rip off, they nickel and dime you for everything. STAY AWAY unless you want to be vomiting and on the toilet for 3 days. And it doesn't matter what you eat - it's everything. It's a good diet though. :)
author: Nirit M.

description: i got laid off in late 09 and hadnt been back to pepes...i just got a job in the financial district and decided to go back.  the burritos are BIG and filling.  you cant go wrong
author: armando g.

description: Love, love, love this place.  Huge burritos, good price.  Awesome beans and rice.  Don't get nachos, though - they use synth cheese, not real stuff.  I've gone here every week for several years.  I like it because it's more authentic Mexican, vs. 360 or other gringo salad-in-a-colored-tortilla places.
author: Leah Y.

description: Not quite as bad as Nick's Crispy Tacos, but they're definitely in the same league.  I should have just canceled my order when I saw that the owner wasn't Mexican, I think he's middle eastern.
author: D C.

description: a slight step above your average food court mexican paste. its a good place for you to get in and out when you realize at 3pm you haven't eaten lunch and you have a conference call at 330. i recommend the vegetarian tostada because i'm a little iffy about meat sitting in steamed water for a long duration.... but thats just me.
author: Aly L.

description: The food here comes fast, and occasionally it's not bad, but I have trouble with the variability.  Sometimes it's just awful.  Sorry.
author: Matt S.

description: Yuck, the carnitas was full of fat a grizzle. Sorry, but sometimes a place doesn't deserve a second chance. Los Compadres Taco Truck is definitely the best answer in this neighborhood.
author: V M.
